coredata.dc:title: How circular economy and green technology can address Sustainable Development Goals?
coredata.dc:creator: Lim, Jeng Shiun
Li, Chunjie
Fan, Yee Van
Klemeš, Jiří Jaromír
coredata.dc:description: This paper introduces the Virtual Special Issue covering some of the latest developments in six research areas: Sustainable Energy System, Sustainable Waste Management, Sustainable Water Management, Sustainable Agriculture and Urban Food Supply, Nexus and Circular Economic and Cleaner Technology. These research topics emerged from the 6th International Conference on Low Carbon asia and beyond 2020 held in 2020. The purpose of this contribution has been to provide a brief introduction to the field and the research results included in this Journal of Cleaner Production Virtual Special Issue.

simple-head.ce:title: How circular economy and green technology can address Sustainable Development Goals?

simple-head.ce:miscellaneous: Handling editor: Cecilia Maria Villas Bôas de Almeida

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: This paper introduces the Virtual Special Issue covering some of the latest developments in six research areas: Sustainable Energy System, Sustainable Waste Management, Sustainable Water Management, Sustainable Agriculture and Urban Food Supply, Nexus and Circular Economic and Cleaner Technology. These research topics emerged from the 6th International Conference on Low Carbon asia and beyond 2020 held in 2020. The purpose of this contribution has been to provide a brief introduction to the field and the research results included in this Journal of Cleaner Production Virtual Special Issue.

ce:section.ce:para: Nearly 5.8% of the decrease in the global energy-related GHG (Greenhouse Gas) emissions from 2019 to 2020 can be seen from the statistical data collected by International Energy Agency (IEA, 2021) are due to the decline of the activities and related reduced fossil fuel consumption caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. As pandemic is slowly transforming into endemic and countries are slowly lifting restrictions, the rebounding of GHG emission is inevitable. The emergence of a new normal, accelerated by COVID-19 in 2020, has changed how practitioners and researchers across the globe are addressing the GHG emission issue (Chernick et al., 2020). This provides both unique opportunities and challenges in reducing emissions while maintaining the nations' rate of development. Several critical topics concerning sustainability and low GHG emission, including renewable energy (Hoang et al., 2021), waste as resources (Peng et al., 2021), cleaner production, circular economy (Saidani et al., 2021), are receiving high research attention recently. International conferences serve as a crucial platform for the science and sustainability community to come together in the face of these challenges.

Over 200 well-versed and experienced professionals banded together at the 6th International Conference on Low Carbon Asia and Beyond 2020 (ICLCA′20), themed “Urban Sustainability towards Human Well-Being” on 1st and September 2, 2020. ICLCA′20 was held as an all-online virtual event. The conference series has been both a prime regional and international forum for academic scientists, researchers, and industry practitioners to share and exchange experiences and research results on the aspect of low-carbon development in Asia and beyond. It also provides a premier platform for researchers and practitioners to discuss and present the most recent trends, innovations, and concerns, as well as practical challenges encountered and solutions adopted for achieving carbon neutrality. The conference addressed the challenges outlined under the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) (United Nations, 2020).

ICLCA′20 was organized entirely online due to the consideration of relatively stringent pandemic measures in Asia and the critical waves during the conference. Thousands of conferences have been held worldwide annually, presenting various efforts to reduce environmental impacts in ICLCA′20. However, the impact of the conference organization itself receives less attention, as highlighted by Nevrlý et al. (2020) in assessing the optimal location for the conference venue. The COVID-19 has altered our lifestyle. It stimulated the discussion of current practices, including e-heath, work from home, virtual conferences, are more effective and environmentally friendlier or to back to the norm, particularly in terms of energy consumption (Klemeš et al., 2020). Jiang et al. (2021) highlight that the energy savings of virtual conferences are generally apparent and less likely to overturn by rebound effects. Jäckle. (2021) stated that virtual events could reduce GHG emissions by up to 90% compared to a physical conference. However, it also depends on the assessed system boundary for the virtual conference (Obringer et al., 2021). An increment is expected nowadays, considering the higher definition of video streaming and efficiency improvement, which induced a higher demand (Masanet et al., 2020). ICLCA′20 is generally successful considering the difficulties and the participant rates. However, the interaction between participants for collaboration deserves more evaluation and brings to the discussion of a hybrid format for the future instead of entirely online (Tao et al., 2021).

The event featured eight plenary speeches, 28 keynote speeches, six breakout sessions with 152 presenters from 14 countries. Contemporary issues, challenges, and the future of sustainable development in Asia were covered in the event. Six major topics were discussed in this joint conference, indicating its multidisciplinary and holistic approach for sustainable solutions. The topics included urban planning and smart cities, sustainable energy, waste and water management, sustainable agriculture and urban food supply, nexus and circular economy, and clean technologies.

A Scientific Committee consisting of 31 world-leading personalities reviewed the 151 papers submitted for the oral and poster presentation for the joint conference. Following further selection procedures, 61 invitations have been sent to the authors to submit manuscripts to the Journal of Cleaner Production, and 39 articles were accepted.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Research work collected in this special issue
ce:section.ce:para: Thirty-nine articles are classified into six categories in this Virtual Special Issue: Sustainable Energy System, Sustainable Waste Management, Sustainable Water Management, Sustainable Agriculture and Urban Food Supply, Nexus and Circular Economic and Cleaner Technology.

There are four articles in Sustainable Energy System. Siyu Yang and a research team from South China University and Technology jointly with the Brno University of Technology to propose a sustainable syngas cryogenic separation process combined with an ammonia absorption refrigeration pre-cooling cycle. Mingce Long led a research team from Shanghai Jiao Tong University and Adi Radian from Technion–Israel Institute of Technology to propose using calcium superphosphate as an inorganic stabilizer for modified-Fenton treatment diesel-contaminated soil with two different exogenous iron sources. Callum Burgess and Wahidul K. Biswas from Curtin University performed an eco-efficiency assessment of wave energy conversion in Western Australia. Dániel Fózer from Budapest University of Technology and Economics, researchers from the Brno University of Technology and the University of Miskolc, conducted a sustainability assessment of biomethanol production via hydrothermal gasification supported by an artificial neural network.

There are nine articles in Sustainable Waste Management. Fei Shen and researchers from Sichuan Agricultural University worked together with Jinguang Hu from The University of Calgary to present a multi-product strategy to valorize kitchen waste towards more sustainable management. Jin Wang and Jiří Jaromír Klemeš from the Brno University of Technology and Min Li with a research team from the Hebei University of Technology to evaluate the effects of salt and solidification treatment on the oil-contaminated soil: a case study in the coastal region of Tianjin, China. Chavalit Ratanatamsku and co-researchers from Chulalongkorn University studied factors affecting technology selection, techno-economic, and environmental sustainability assessment of a novel zero-waste system for food waste and wastewater management. Norhuda Abdul Manaf from Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Dia Milani from CSIRO Energy Center, and Ali Abbas from The University of Sydney proposed an intelligent platform for evaluating the investment in low-emissions technology for clean power production under ETS policy. Kok Sin Woon and Jun Keat Ooi from Xiamen University Malaysia and Haslenda Hashim from Universiti Teknologi Malaysia developed a multi-objective model to optimize country-scale municipal solid waste management with economic and environmental objectives for a case study in Malaysia. Muhammad Imtiaz Rashid and Khurram Shahzad from King Abdulaziz University conducted a study for food waste recycling for compost production and its economic and environmental assessment as circular economy indicators of solid waste management. Carlos Ariel and co-researchers from Universidad Nacional de Colombia performed a comparative environmental life cycle assessment of orange peel waste in present productive chains. Awais Bokhari with Jiří Jaromír Klemeš from the Brno University of Technology, Amit Kumar and Zhi-Guo Yu from Nanjing University of Information Science and Technology conducted a state-of-the-art review of Greenhouse gas emissions from Indian hydropower reservoirs. Peng Jiang from Sichuan University, Jieyu Zhou from the National University of Singapore, and co-researchers from the Brno University of Technology, Meimei Zheng from Shanghai Jiao Tong University performed data analysis of resident engagement and sentiments in social media to enable better household waste segregation and recycling.

Four articles analysed the Sustainable Water Management topic. Ivan Radelyuk, with a research team from Lund University and the Brno University of Technology, examines oil refinery and water pollution in the context of sustainable development in developing and developed countries. Yoke Kin Wan and Jo Yee Ho from the University of Nottingham Malaysia, Jecksin Ooi from UCSI University Kuala Lumpur, and Viknesh Andiappan from Heriot-Watt University Malaysia synthesized the wastewater treatment process (WWTP) and supplier selection via the Fuzzy Analytic Hierarchy Process (FAHP). Jinhua Li led a research team from Shanghai Jiao Tong University and Yang Xianzhi from Yunnan Appraisal Center for Ecological and Environmental Engineering to analyze 146 rural decentralized wastewater treatment facilities surrounding Erhai Lake. In another work, Jinhua Li led a research team from Shanghai Jiao Tong University and Yang Xianzhi from Yunnan Appraisal Center for Ecological and Environmental Engineering to evaluate the treatment and reuse of tailwater in Erhai Lake.

Five articles contributed to Sustainable Agriculture and Urban Food Supply topic. Yoke Kin Wan led a research team from Taylor's University, Raymond R.Tan from De La Salle University, and Viknesh Andiappan from Heriot-Watt University Malaysia proposed a strategic planning model to optimize perennial crops based on cost and discounted carbon value. Sheng Zhou led a research team from Shanghai Academy of Agricultural Sciences, and Limin Lu from Pudong New Area Agro-Technology Extension Center evaluated the effects of different fertilization methods on ammonia volatilization from rice paddies. Jun Wu from Harbin Engineering University worked with Jian Lu, and Cui Zhang from the Chinese Academy of Sciences conducted a study related to cleaner production of salt-tolerance vegetables in coastal saline soils using reclaimed water irrigation and observations from an alleviated accumulation of endocrine-disrupting chemicals and environmental burden. Michael Francis D. Benjamin and Beatriz A. Belmonte from University of Santo Tomas, Jey-R. S. Ventura and Joemer A. Adorna Jr. from College of Engineering and Agro-Industrial Technology University of the Philippines Los Baños, Kim Patrick H.Sangalang from National Research Council of the Philippines, and Viknesh Andiappan from Heriot-Watt University Malaysia studied the optimal synthesis of Philippine agricultural residue-based integrated biorefinery via the P-graph method under supply and demand constraints. Lijun Luo led a research team from Shanghai Agrobiological Gene Center, and Xianxian Zhang from the Shanghai Academy of Agricultural Sciences proposed a novel water-saving and drought-resistance rice variety that promotes phosphorus absorption through root secreting organic acid compounds to stabilize yield under water-saving conditions.

There are five articles on Nexus and Circular Economic topics. Emelia Sari led a research team from Universitas Trisakti, Azanizawati Ma'aram from Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Awaluddin Mohamed Shaharoun from the Islamic University of Madinah, Abdoulmohammad Gholamzadeh Chofreh, and co-researchers from the Brno University of Technology to measure sustainable cleaner maintenance hierarchical contributions of the car manufacturing industry. Giada La Scalia led a research team from the University of Palermo to scale green geopolymeric mortars manufacturing towards a Circular Economy. Nor Erniza Mohammad Rozali, and Xian Biao Oh from Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, worked with Peng Yen Liew from Universiti Teknologi Malaysia and Jiří Jaromír Klemeš from the Brno University of Technology to design an integrated energy-water system using Pinch Analysis and conducted a nexus study of energy-water-carbon emissions. Nitin Dutt Chaturvedi from the Indian Institute of Technology Patna and Zainuddin Abdul Manan from Universiti Teknologi Malaysia reviewed batch process integration for resource conservation toward cleaner production. Pen-Chi Chiang and Shu-Yuan Pan from National Taiwan University, Kinjal J.Shah and Zhaoyang You from Nanjing Tech University, Ingyu Lee Hyunook Kim from the University of Seoul, Jian-Ming Zheng from Jimei University reviewed current barriers, strategies, and innovative technologies for green transportation for sustainability.

There are 12 articles on the Cleaner Technology topic. Mazura Jusoh and her research team from Universiti Teknologi Malaysia, Shafirah Samsuri and Nurul Aini Amran from Universiti Teknologi PETRONAS, Nor Zanariah Safiei from Universiti Kuala Lumpur Malaysian Institute of Chemical & Bioengineering Technology evaluated design characteristics and process optimization to preserve total phenolic content (TPC) in cucumber juice concentrate using non-thermal progressive freeze concentration. Ruixue Wang and co-researchers from Shanghai Polytechnic University studied full components recovery of organic matter and indium from discarded liquid crystal display panels. Deyi Wu led a research team from Shanghai Jiao Tong University to develop a closed-loop sustainable scheme for silver recovery from water using reusable thiol-grafted graphene oxide. Khaled S.Baamran and Muhammad Tahir from Universiti Teknologi Malaysia performed steam reforming of phenol toward cleaner hydrogen production over bimetallic Ni/Ti modified zinc titanate perovskite in tandem with kinetic model development. Gang Zhao and his co-researchers from Wuhan University of Science and Technology worked with Yancai Chen and his co-researchers from Wuhan Iron & Steel Co. to develop a new dust removal technology used in hot rolling mills based on atomized spray with higher dedusting efficiency. Katarzyna Mikula led a research team from Wroclaw University of Science and Technology and Konstantinos Moustakas from the National Technical University of Athens to study drying technologies improvements with emphasis on cleaner solutions production with higher energy efficiency and reduced emission. Qiang Yu from South China Agricultural University, Yanling Wang and Qinghua Zhang from Jiangxi Agricultural University, Xiaoyan Chen and Fan Wang from University of Chinese Academic of Sciences, Xinpeng Tian from Chinese Academy of Science, and Yueshu Gao from Shanghai Jiao Tong University studied a deep eutectic solvent that assists Bacillus australimaris in transforming alkali lignin waste into small aromatic compounds. Habuer and Takeshi Fujiwara from Okayama University and MasakiTakaoka from Kyoto University analyzed the response of anthropogenic mercury release in China to the Minamata Convention on Mercury based on a hypothetical expectation. Phung K. Le led a research team from the Ho Chi Minh City University of Technology, worked with Kien A.Le and Nghiep Q.Pham from Institute for Tropical Technology and Environmental Protection, and Hai M.Duong from the National University of Singapore to propose green recycling of fly ash into heat and sound insulation composite aerogels reinforced by recycled polyethylene terephthalate fibers. Karayannis Vayos from the University of Western Macedonia, Konstantinos Nikolaos Kokkinos and Eftihia Nathanail from the University of Thessaly, Konstantinos Moustakas from the National Technical University of Athens conducted a study for comparative analysis of Statistical and Computational Intelligence methodologies for the prediction of traffic-induced fine particulate matter and NO2. Surisa Suwannarangsee led a research team from National Science and Technology Development Agency, Xin-Qing Zhao and co-researchers from Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Sudarat Tharad from Burapha University, and Santi Chuetor from the King Mongkut's University of Technology North Bangkok produced D-galacturonic acid from pomelo peel using the crude enzyme from recombinant Trichoderma reesei expressing a heterologous exopolygalacturonase gene. Haslenda Hashim, with a research team from Universiti Teknologi Malaysia and the Brno University of Technology, proposed an Integrated Linear Programming and Analytical Hierarchy Process method for diesel/biodiesel/butanol to reduce diesel emissions.

This VSI introduction paper addresses a selection of research studies from the four ICLCA conferences in 2020. The studies included in this VSI investigated topics that can be classified into six categories: namely Sustainable Energy System, Sustainable Waste Management, Sustainable Water Management, Sustainable Agriculture and Urban Food Supply, Nexus and Circular Economic and Cleaner Technology. The solutions to the studied problems shed light on how circular economy and green technology can address Sustainable Development Goals. The Guest Editors believe that the papers selected for this VSI will contribute to the JCLEPRO research public.

ce:acknowledgment.ce:para: The financial support from the EU supported project Sustainable Process Integration Laboratory – SPIL funded as project No. CZ.02.1.01/0.0/0.0/15_003/0000456, by Czech Republic Operational Programme Research and Development, Education, Priority 1: Strengthening capacity for quality research under the collaboration agreement with Universiti Technologi Malaysia is gratefully acknowledged.
